Farrautoa, John N. Armorb aColumbia University, Earth and Environmental Engineering Department, NY, NY 10027, United States bGlobalCatalysis.com L.L.C., 1608 Barkwood Dr., Oreï¬� eld, PA 18069, USA Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 182 Temperature-programmed reduction of nickel steam reforming catalyst with glucose Feng Chenga, Valerie Duponta, Martyn V. Twiggb aEnergy Research Institute, School of Chemical and Process Engineering, The University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, UK bTwigg Scientiï¬� c & Technical Ltd., Caxton, Cambridge, CB23 3PQ, UK The reactivity between a NiO catalyst and char from glucose pyrolysis under N2 was studied. The NiO reduction started at 420 C and underwent two stages during a TPR process. A complete reduction without carbon remaining was achieved when the mass ratio of glucose to the catalyst was 1:10 under our experimental condition. This work has a potential implication to exploiting biomass resources via chemical looping technology. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 1 Understanding the role of Keggin type heteropolyacid catalysts for glycerol acetylation using toluene as an entrainer S.S. Kalea, U. Armbrustera, R. Eckelta, U. Bentrupa, S.B. Umbarkarb, M.K. Dongareb,c, A. Martina aLeibniz-Institut fÃ¼r Katalyse e. V. an der UniversitÃ¤t Rostock, Albert-Einstein-Str. 29a, D-18059 Rostock, Germany bCatalysis Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411008, India cMojj Engineering Systems Ltd., 15-81/B, MIDC, Bhosari, Pune 411026, India High BrÃ¸nsted acidity is required to achieve good performance. Preservation of the Keggin structure of the HPAs is mandatory. Toluene as entrainer enables high triacetin yields. H4SiW12O40/SiO2 reached selectivity to triacetin of 71% at complete glycerol conversion. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 9 Regular Articles iv Contents Au/Cuâ€“Feâ€“Laâ€“Al2O3: A highly active, selective and stable catalysts for preferential oxidation of carbon monooxide Xun Sun, Huijuan Su, Qingquan Lin, Chung Han, Yuhua Zheng, Libo Sun, Caixia Qi School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Shandong Applied Research Center of Gold Nanotechnology (Au-SDARC), Yantai 264005, PR China Copper precursor was added to a FLA support via wetness impregnation method before Au deposition. High dispersion of Au nanparticles, formation of AuCu alloy, and the close contact of single or alloyed Au nanoparticles to CuO species which makes Au partially positively charged. Copper addition improved overall performance for PROX but lowered activity in O2-rich stream. More Au-CuO interfaces or positively charged gold play a crucial role in promoting CO2 formation in CO-PROX reaction. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 19 PtSnNa@SUZ-4-catalyzed propane dehydrogenation Hualan Zhoua, Jingjing Gonga, Bolian Xua, Lei Yua,b, Yining Fana aKey Laboratory of Mesoscopic Chemistry of MOE, Jiangsu Provincial Key Laboratory of Nanotechnology, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China bJiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Material and Environmental Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225002, China Propane dehydrogenation using SUZ-4 zeolite-supported catalyst. Mechanism studies on the sodium ion content effect. Practical and stable catalyst that led to high propane conversion and high propylene selectivity. Walkerb aDepartment of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States bChemistry & Biochemistry Department, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States Ni/YSZ cermet anodes inï¬� ltrated with aluminum titanate (ALT) have reduced degradation rates and improved performance. XRD and Raman data show that the composition of Ni/YSZ doped with ALT depends sensitively on processing temperature with several material phases (Zr5Ti7O24, NiAl2O4, and monoclinic YSZ) appearing only under speciï¬� c sintering conditions. Ex situ analysis of Ni/YSZ anodes inï¬� ltrated with ALT show signiï¬� cantly diminished coarsening after operation in fuel cell mode at 850 C. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 36 Highly efficient Ru/carbon catalysts prepared by pyrolysis of supported Ru complex towards the hydrogen production from ammonia borane Miriam Navlani-GarcÃ­aa, Kohsuke Moria,b,c, Ai Nozakia, Yasutaka Kuwaharaa,b, Hiromi Yamashitaa,b aDivision of Materials and Manufacturing Science, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, 2-1 Yamada-oka, Suita, Japan bUnit of Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries, Kyoto University, Katsura, Kyoto 615-8520, Japan cPRESTO, JST, Honcho, Kawaguchi, Saitama 332-0012, Japan Highly eï¬ƒ cient Ru/carbon catalysts for the hydrogen production from ammonia borane were synthesized. Metal complex decomposition temperature plays a pivotal role in determining the catalysts features. A very high TOF number of 670 mol H2/mol metal min was achieved with the best performing catalyst. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 45 Contents v Catalytic properties of CuMgAlO catalyst and degradation mechanism in CWPO of methyl orange Jing Han, Hong-Yan Zeng, Sheng Xu, Chao-Rong Chen, Xiao-Jun Liu College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, Hunan, China Cu-loaded MgAl hydrotalcite catalysts were synthesized by impregnation method. The synthesized catalysts were further used for catalytic wet peroxidation (CWPO) of methyl orange (MO). The CuMgAlO catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity, stable performance. The degradation mechanism of MO was determined. Synthesis of Ti(SO4)O solid acid nano-catalyst and its application for biodiesel production from used cooking oil Jabbar Gardya, Ali Hassanpoura, Xiaojun Laia, Mukhtar H. Ahmedb aSchool of Chemical and Process Engineering, University of Leeds, LS2 9JT Leeds, UK bNanotechnology Integrated Bioengineering Centre, University of Ulster, Jordanstown, BT37 0QB Belfast, UK A novel solid acid nanocatalyst, Ti(SO4)O, was synthesised from TiO2 and chlorosulphonic acid. The XRD and SAED data conï¬� rms the JCPDS-ICDD card â„– 04-011-4951 for Ti(SO4)O. We examined the catalytic activity, stability and reusability of Ti(SO4)O. The FAME yield from UCO was 97.1% at optimum process conditions using Ti(SO4)O. Produced biodiesel from UCO satisï¬� ed ASTM D6751and EN 14214 standards. Enhancing catalytic performance of activated carbon supported Rh catalyst on heterogeneous hydroformylation of 1-hexene via introducing surface oxygen-containing groups Minghui Tana,b, Ding Wangc, Peipei Aib, Guoguo Liub, Mingbo Wua, Jingtang Zhenga, Guohui Yangb,d, Yoshiharu Yoneyamab, Noritatsu Tsubakib aState Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, China bDepartment of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, University of Toyama, Gofuku 3190, Toyama 930-8555, Japan cCollege of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science & Technology, Shanghai 200093, China dState Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, China Functional groups on catalyst obviously inï¬‚ uence heterogeneous hydroformylation. The Rh/AC-80 had the highest n/i ratio of 2.3, almost double to that of raw Rh/AC. Abundant functional groups on catalyst suppressed hydrogenation of hexene. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 53 High thermal conductive core-shell structured Al2O3@Al composite supported cobalt catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Da Wanga,b, Congbiao Chena, Jungang Wanga, Litao Jiaa, Bo Houa, Debao Lia aState Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China Al2O3@Al composite is prepared via NaOH corrosion method. The Al2O3@Al composite has a macro-mesoporous structure. The thermal conductive coeï¬ƒ cient of Co/Al2O3@Al is 13â€“98 times of Co/Al2O3. Co/Al2O3@Al exhibits high CO conversion, C5+ selectivity and low CH4 selectivity. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 60 Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 72 Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 81 vi Contents Silica is preferred over various single and mixed oxides as support for CO2â€“assisted cobaltâ€“catalyzed oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane Rajesh Koiralaa, Robert Buechela, Sotiris E. Pratsinisa, Alfons Baikerb aParticle Technology Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering, ETH Zurich, Sonneggstrasse 3, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland bDepartment of Chemistry and Applied Biosciences, ETH Zurich, HÃ¶nggerberg, HCI, CH-8093 Zurich, Switzerland Several cobalt loaded single and mixed supports were prepared by ï¬‚ ame spray pyrolysis. Silica support preferred over others for CO2-assisted cobalt-catalyzed ODHE reaction. State of CoOx species highly inï¬‚ uenced by the type of support. Cobalt silicate appeared to be an important structure responsible for high catalytic activity. Presence of CO2 is essential to improve the performance of Co/SiO2 catalyst. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 96 Photocatalytic degradation of 4-chlorophenol on titanium dioxide modified with Cu(II) or Cr(III) ion under visible light irradiation Naoto Nishiyamaa, Keisuke Kozasab, Suzuko Yamazakib aDivision of Environmental Science and Engineering, Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi 753-8512, Japan bDivision of Earth Science, Biology, and Chemistry, Graduate School of Sciences and Technology for Innovation, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi 753-8512, Japan For developing the visible light responsive TiO2 by using Cu 2+ ion, the graft method is more advantageous than the sol-gel method. Photocatalytic activity of Cu-grafted TiO2 is affected by the number-density of Cu2+ on the surface. Cr-doped TiO2 is superior to Cu-grafted TiO2 from the viewpoint of the higher photocatalytic activity as well as the chemical stability in acidic wastewater. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 109 Ethylene polymerization by Cr(III) salts on acidic carriers Max P. McDaniel, Kathy S. Clear Bldg. 84G, Phillips Research Center, Highways 60 & 123A, Bartlesville, OK 74004, United States Cr(III) compounds can be activated for ethylene polymerization by acidic carriers. Such Cr(III) catalysts do not pass through the carcinogenic hexavalent state. Cr(III) catalysts produce HDPE with very broad MW. Cr(III) catalysts are very sensitive to hydrogen as a MW regulator. Cr(III) catalysts are compatible with Ziegler and metallocene catalysts. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 116 Synthesis of BiOBr/carbon quantum dots microspheres with enhanced photoactivity and photostability under visible light irradiation Chenhui Zhaoa,b, Wei Lia,b, Ying Lianga,b, Yi Tiana,b, Qiuyu Zhanga,b aDepartment of Applied Chemistry, College of Science, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xiâ€™an 710072, China bKey Laboratory of Space Physics and Chemistry, Ministry of Education, Northwestern Polytechnical University, P.O. Box 624, Xiâ€™an 710072, China A novel BiOBr/CQDs microsphere material was successfully synthesized. The BiOBr/CQDs materials exhibit enhanced photoactivity under visible light irradiation. The CQDs play an important role for enhancing the photoactivity. The BiOBr/CQDs materials exhibit rapid separation of photoexcited electron-holes. This BiOBr/ CQDs material exhibits superior visible-light absorption ability. Applied Catalysis A: General, 527 (2016) 127 Contents vii Steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis model hydrocarbons and catalyst deactivation Itsaso Barbarias, Gartzen Lopez, Maider Amutio, Maite Artetxe, Jon Alvarez, Aitor Arregi, Javier Bilbao, Martin Olazar Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Basque Country UPV/EHU, P.O. Box 644, E48080 Bilbao, Spain n-Hexane, 1-hexene, tetradecane and toluene are selected as model compounds of the plastics waste pyrolysis stream. The conversion obtained with linear hydrocarbons is higher (>92%) than with aromatics (82%). Catalyst deactivation rate order is toluene > 1-hexene > tetradecane > n-hexane. The nature of the coke deposited on the catalyst varies depending on the model compound used. Hydrogen production from catalytic steam reforming of phenol with bimetallic nickel-cobalt catalyst on various supports Walid Nabgana,b, Tuan Amran Tuan Abdullaha,b, Ramli Matb, Bahador Nabgana,b, Sugeng Triwahyonoc, Adnan Ripina aCentre of Hydrogen Energy, Institute of Future Energy, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, UTM Skudai, 81310 Johor, Malaysia bDepartment of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Chemical & Energy Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, UTM Skudai, 81310 Johor, Malaysia cCentre for Sustainable Nanomaterials (CSNano), Department of Chemistry, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, UTM Skudai, 81310 Johor, Malaysia Ni-Co supported by CeO2, ZrO2, La2O3, -Al2O3, and -Al2O3 were used for hydrogen production from phenol steam reforming reaction. The most active catalyst was Ni-Co/ZrO2 because of having the tetragonal phase structure which is favour in reforming processes. The catalyst test shows that the phenol conversion achieved at 650 C is 75.9% and hydrogen yield is 80.7% for Ni-Co/ZrO2 catalyst. Supported molybdenum oxides provide high FA selectivities (70%). Signiï¬� cant catalyst deactivation but reaching steady state activity. Kinetic model based on Mars- Van Krevelen mechanism.
